channel.title: Creating a new bot
channel.description:
Hey All. I'm new to this form and programming in this way but i was wondering if someone could help me out. I want to create a hole new bot client and add scripts to just like the recent NeXus bot did through re sellers. I'm not doing this to gain personal profic or anything i just have an interest in bots and how they work and the NeXus bot is exactly what i want to learn about.
what programming language was the NeXus bot made with With Jave completely? With C++ as the client's language and Java as the scripts that tell the client what to do? Or with this Language called NeXus ?- http://nexuslang.org/
What's Better Reflection or Injection ?
If i was to go about creating a new bot client and everything like the Nexus how would i go about it ?

item.title: Creating a new bot
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“Clarkie, post:5, topic:442419”]Thanks everyone for your help. Really appreciate it. Got some ideas now.
Something along the lines of a Java bot that communicates with an openGL wrapper through the JNI. Just getting my head around intercepting the OpenGL calls going to the graphics card…

Never done anything like this before so it’s going to take me awhile.

Is possible to intercept openGL calls and automatically log them in a txt file. Then matching them with a sprite in the game? - might be talking a lot of crap sorry.[/quote]

We already have a working GL bot that works by replacing the opengl32.dll file. It interfaces with Simba: https://github.com/silabsoft/SimbaGL

As for the logging, you can use GLIntercept. It works the same way (by replacing the opengl32.dll file) and you can configure it to log to a file and have pictures of each modification to a frame. I don’t know if it supports automatically associating a command with a frame, you might have to do a bit of manual work on that.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a new bot

@Clarkie wrote:

Thanks everyone for your help. Really appreciate it. Got some ideas now.

Is possible to intercept openGL calls and automatically log them in a txt file. Then matching them with a sprite in the game? - might be talking a lot of crap sorry.

item.title: Creating a new bot
item.dc:creator: @packersfa52 packersfa52
item.description:
@packersfa52 wrote:

Nexus uses reflection, made in Java, if you want a good look on how to make one I’d say take a look at one of the older versions, like 15.xx+; or just look at powerbot. The only real difference was how they accessed the fields.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a new bot
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Programming languages are just tools. That being said, different tools and toolkits are better suited to different approaches. For reflection, Java is really your only option; it’s also your best bet if you want to do bytecode injection. If you want to make an OpenGL bot you’ll probably want a toolchain that can compile to native, so C/C++ (or almost any of the Visual Studio languages if you’re on Windows) would work. For a screen scraper / color bot you can essentially use anything that has the appropriate I/O libraries.

Of course, you can build all the other parts that don’t interface with the game itself (e.g. the scripting system, user interfaces) in whatever language you see fit.

As for which approach is ‘better’, that’s your call really. All of them aim at solving the same problem. At the moment I’d probably say a OpenGL / DX bot is your best bet since it’s been three months since we’ve made any changes and the bot Silab + I worked on still works just fine. Reflection / injection bots require quite a bit of maintenance and updating due to obfuscation.

Read full topic
